Summary I am a highly accomplished, results-oriented finance executive with more than 15 years of progressing experience in finance and operations management within start-ups and global multi-billion dollar organizations. I have demonstrated ability to streamline business operations that drive growth and increase efficiency and bottom-line profit. I possess strong qualifications in developing and implementing financial controls and processes in addition to productivity improvements, and change management. I am a quantitative thinker with the ability to use numbers to communicate and validate critical concepts and to extract insight from data. Finally, I exhibit solid leadership, communication and interpersonal skills to establish rapport with all levels of staff and management. 
 
Specialties: Key areas of expertise include but are not limited to Managing, Employee Development, Budgeting, Cash Flow Analysis, Forecasting, Capital Evaluations, Financial Analysis, and Financial Modeling. Organized and creative with the ability to prioritize and adapt quickly to change. Outstanding communication skills in any gathering. Experience Budget, Capital Planning & Forecasting Director Associate/UKHC University of Kentucky HealthCare June 2015  – Present (3 months) Lexington, Kentucky Finance Leader/Site CFO INVISTA October 2013  –  June 2015  (1 year 9 months) Victoria, Texas Role: Leader – CFO for the Site and Businesses operated at the Site 
• Deliver world-class (i.e. optimized capability vs. cost) management-based financial reporting (including reality-based plant P&Ls, scorecards and bet tracking) and analysis in support of the site and business visions that maximizes the profitability and long-term NPV of Intermediates  
* Ensure economic thinking tools/concepts are employed in analyses prepared for the site 
* Understand key market drivers and the site’s relative competitive position (current and long-term) and identify strategies to drive value  
* Set clear expectations and drive clear site accountability/ownership for meeting internal controls expectations and for adherence to site procedures and policies relating to financial related processes managed at the site 
 
Role: Member – Site Leadership Team  
* Ensure understanding of the financials throughout the site leadership 
* Challenge the site leadership team to deliver superior returns by setting high expectations for leadership team members and their staff and the capabilities providing services to the site 
* Partner with key site and business capabilities in assessing talent/capability and establishing base expectations. Don’t accept average performance as being “good”. 
 
Role: Site Finance Team Leader/Mentor/Coach 
* Hire, develop, and retain world-class finance talent 
* Align capabilities of staff to optimize comparative advantages of entire team and to effectively and efficiently deliver services and results 
* Provide each employee with the vision, decision rights (as earned), feedback, and rewards necessary to deliver world-class finance capability to the site and business Chief Financial Officer Fabric.com June 2011  –  October 2013  (2 years 5 months) Marietta, GA Strategy  
* As a true business partner to the President/CEO, assessing organizational performance against both the annual budget and company's long-term strategy. 
* Developing tools and systems to provide critical financial and operational information to the President/CEO and make actionable recommendations on both strategy and operations. 
* Assisting in establishing yearly objectives and meeting agendas, and selecting and engaging outside consultants. Oversee long-term budgetary planning and costs management in alignment with company's strategic plan. 
 
Financial Planning and Analysis 
* Preparing and maintaining regular financial planning reports; Monthly profit and loss forecast (vs. budget); Weekly 13 week cash flow forecast. 
* Developing and executing analysis of various business initiatives (e.g., moving facilities, asset acquisition, new service launches). 
* Engaging Corporate (Amazon) to develop short-, medium-, and long-term financial plans and projections. 
* Developing and utilizing forward-looking, predictive models and activity-based financial analyses to provide insight into the organization's operations and business plans. 
* Overseeing weekly cash management; Approving weekly payables; Executing check signing 
 
Accounting Activities 
* Overseeing preparation of month-end, quarter-end and year-end financial statements  
* Reviewing all month-end closing activities including general ledger maintenance, balance sheet reconciliations and corporate/overhead cost allocation 
* Ensuring maintenance of appropriate internal controls and financial procedures.  
* Serving as a key point of contact for external auditors; Managing preparation and support of all external audits Finance Controller - Indiana Campus Amazon.com March 2007  –  June 2011  (4 years 4 months) Indianapolis, IN * Senior leader responsible for controllership of the Indiana regional fulfillment operations. The Indiana region is one of the largest campuses with $150M+ in operating costs and over 3,000 employees. Responsibilities include supporting three Operations General Managers and providing leadership to finance and procurement staff of 20+ people.  
* Primary responsibilities included ensuring financial controls were in place and adhered to. Lead the budgeting and forecasting efforts for the FC. Managed the weekly, monthly and quarterly financial results. Worked with the facility to drive process improvements and cost savings. 
* Major accomplishments include successfully building operating plans, cost structure, staffing model (both hourly and salary), and capital plans for FC. This plan allowed the Indianapolis FC to be the most successful building startup in Amazon’s history. Received and shipped more volume, while having a lower fixed and variable cost than 88% of the other facilities. 
* Being a new FC, 36 of 40 managers were new to Amazon. Held training classes to ensure Senior Leaders, Operation’s Managers and Area Managers not only understood metrics but were also able to use these metrics to manage the business.  
* During year 2, lead cost, labor and capital initiative that allowed the FC to become the second largest FC in the network. Senior Budget Analyst University of Kentucky HealthCare May 2004  –  April 2007  (3 years) Lexington, KY * Developing, administered, monitored, and recorded the status of the annual operating budget for the entire Hospital. Involved meeting with physicians and administrators to discuss volume projects, shifts in business practices and revised organizational goals. 
* Provided timely, accurate and informative analysis of the current status of operations - including clinical activity, revenues, expenses, and cash flows to senior and line managers. 
* Facilitated departmental budget accountability by training managers to use financial management tools. 
* Worked with the Director of Finance and senior management to incorporate the professional colleges at the University of Kentucky into one corporate UK Healthcare Enterprise. 
* Supervised and training a group of financial analyst 
* Responsible for month-end accounting closure including calculating and processing accruals, creating and reviewing journal entries for accuracies, tying the general journal to the financial systems and reconciling differences. Buyer Montaplast of North America January 2003  –  May 2004  (1 year 5 months) Frankfort, KY * Sourced, evaluated and transitioned new suppliers into current supplier base, making sure to work within a restricted budget to ensure profitability on new projects. 
* Worked with the company’s engineers and laborers to increase production efficiency.  
* Worked with suppliers to achieve cost reductions on currently purchased material, negotiated with vendors on jobs, and wrote purchase orders to authorize labor.  
* Handled all quality issues from the time they were opened until closed.  
* Greatest accomplishment was creating a database that saved the company money by effectively tracking cost-down opportunities and also pursuing back-pay from suppliers who had failed to honor our initial purchase order contract.
